hints_html: The factored bottom should make partial fractions a natural choice for a technique to attempt this problem.
hints_latex:
The factored bottom should make partial fractions a natural choice for a
technique to attempt this problem.
hints_raw: The factored bottom should make partial fractions a natural choice for a technique to attempt this problem.
question: 4 (c)
sols_html:
We proceed by partial fractions. Let A and B be constants such that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{x}{(2-x)(1 + 2x)} = \frac{A}{2-x} + \frac{B}{1 + 2x} = \frac{A(1+2x) + B(2-x)}{(2-x)(1 + 2x)}\end{aligned}\]

Since the denominators are the same, the numerators must be equal and hence

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x = A(1+2x) + B(2-x)\end{aligned}\]

Now, since this equality holds for all values of x, we can plug in specific values for x to get the coefficients. At \(x=2\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2 = A(1 + 2(2)) + B(2-(2)) = 5A\end{aligned}\]

and so \(A = \tfrac{2}{5}\). At \(x = -\tfrac{1}{2}\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} -\tfrac{1}{2} = A(1 + 2(-\tfrac{1}{2})) + B(2-(-\tfrac{1}{2})) = \tfrac{5}{2}B\end{aligned}\]

and so \(B = \tfrac{-1}{5}\). Hence, we have

\[\begin{aligned} &\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x}{(2-x)(1 + 2x)}\,dx\\ &= \int_{0}^{1} \frac{\tfrac{2}{5}}{2-x}\,dx + \int_{0}^{1} \frac{\tfrac{-1}{5}}{1 + 2x}\,dx \\ &= \left.\left(\frac25 \ln|2-x|(-1) - \frac15\ln|1 + 2x|\frac12\right)\right|_{0}^{1} \\ &= \left.\left(\frac{-2}{5}\ln|2-x| - \frac{1}{10}\ln|1 + 2x|\right)\right|_{0}^{1}\\ &= \frac{-2}{5}\ln|2-1| - \frac{1}{10}\ln|1 + 2(1)| - \frac{-2}{5}\ln|2-0| - \frac{1}{10}\ln|1 + 2(0)|\\ &= - \frac{1}{10}\ln|3| - \frac{-2}{5}\ln|2|\\ &= - \frac{\ln(3)}{10} + \frac{2\ln(2)}{5}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We proceed by partial fractions. Let A and B be constants such that

:<math>
\frac{x}{(2-x)(1 + 2x)} = \frac{A}{2-x} + \frac{B}{1 + 2x} = \frac{A(1+2x) + B(2-x)}{(2-x)(1 + 2x)}
</math>

Since the denominators are the same, the numerators must be equal and hence

:<math>
\displaystyle x = A(1+2x) + B(2-x)
</math>

Now, since this equality holds for all values of x, we can plug in specific values for x to get the coefficients. At <math> x=2 </math>, we have

:<math>
\displaystyle 2 = A(1 + 2(2)) + B(2-(2)) = 5A
</math>

and so <math> A = \tfrac{2}{5} </math>. At <math>x = -\tfrac{1}{2}</math>, we have

:<math>
-\tfrac{1}{2} = A(1 + 2(-\tfrac{1}{2})) + B(2-(-\tfrac{1}{2})) = \tfrac{5}{2}B
</math>

and so <math> B = \tfrac{-1}{5} </math>. Hence, we have

:<math>
\begin{align}
&\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x}{(2-x)(1 + 2x)}\,dx\\
&= \int_{0}^{1} \frac{\tfrac{2}{5}}{2-x}\,dx + \int_{0}^{1} \frac{\tfrac{-1}{5}}{1 + 2x}\,dx \\
&= \left.\left(\frac25 \ln|2-x|(-1) - \frac15\ln|1 + 2x|\frac12\right)\right|_{0}^{1} \\
&= \left.\left(\frac{-2}{5}\ln|2-x| - \frac{1}{10}\ln|1 + 2x|\right)\right|_{0}^{1}\\
&= \frac{-2}{5}\ln|2-1| - \frac{1}{10}\ln|1 + 2(1)| - \frac{-2}{5}\ln|2-0| - \frac{1}{10}\ln|1 + 2(0)|\\
&= - \frac{1}{10}\ln|3| - \frac{-2}{5}\ln|2|\\
&= - \frac{\ln(3)}{10} + \frac{2\ln(2)}{5}
\end{align}.
</math>
statement_html:
Compute the following integrals. (Leave your answers in terms of \(e\) or \(\ln()\).)

\[\begin{aligned} I = \int_0^1 \frac{x}{(2-x)(1+2x)}\,dx\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Compute the following integrals. (Leave your answers in terms of <math>e</math> or <math>\ln()</math>.)

:<math> I = \int_0^1 \frac{x}{(2-x)(1+2x)}\,dx</math>
